bunpro.meaning_warning: ばっかり, ばっか, ばかし, and ばっかし are all fairly common casual variations of ばかり
bunpro.writeup: When used after verbs followed by theconjunction particleて, or nouns, theadverbial particleばかりhighlights that 'nothing but (A) is being done', or 'only (A) exists'. In relation to verbs, てばかり is often followed by いる, as a modified version of the standard ている. However, adding いる is not a requirement, and the same nuance may be conveyed without it.When a sentence consists of a part (A) and a part (B), ばかり will be followed by either で (with verbs or nouns), or いて (only with verbs). This is when ばかり appears directly before the sentence conjunction point, and other combinations are possible (such as ばかりだから).It should be noted that the で with ばかり here is not the particle で, but theconjunctive formof the auxiliary verb,だ.Fun Factばかり is rarely seen using kanji, but it originally comes from許り (sometimes計る). This kanji means 'to let off', or 'to let through', and implies that (A) is the only thing that is being 'permitted' in a specific situation.

examples.japanese: 先生はいつも怒ってばかりいる。
examples.english: Our teacher does nothing but yell.

examples.japanese: 最近はお菓子ばかり食べているから、お腹がでてきた。
examples.english: Recently, I've been eating nothing but junk, so my stomach is bulging out.

examples.japanese: 先月生まれた息子がずっと泣いてばかりいて、全然寝れない。
examples.english: My son who was born last month does nothing but cry, so I can't sleep.

examples.japanese: 彼は毎日残業してばかりで、全然家の事を手伝ってくれない。
examples.english: All he does is work overtime everyday, and he won't help me with house chores.

examples.japanese: 彼は口を開けると文句ばかりで、一緒にいるだけで疲れる。
examples.english: When he opens his mouth, all he can do is complain, so just being with him is exhausting.

examples.japanese: 彼はいつも嘘ばかり言っている。
examples.english: He does nothing but tell lies.

examples.japanese: 私の弟はゲームをしてばかりですよ。
examples.english: My little brother does nothing but play video games.

examples.japanese: 甘い物を食べてばかりいると、虫歯が増える。
examples.english: If you only/do nothing but eat sweets, you will have more cavities.

examples.japanese: 人生つらいことばかりではない。いい日もあるよ。
examples.english: Life is not always (nothing but) hard. There are good days too.

examples.japanese: いつももらってばかりですみません。
examples.english: It seems that I do nothing but receive (gifts) from you. Sorry about that.

false_friends.meaning: Not only…but also, As well as
Not only ~ but ~ also, Not just ~ but ~ also
(Only) continue to, Keep on -ing, More and more
Simply because, Only because, Just because, Simply on account of

dojg.description: A particle which indicates that something is the only thing or state which exists, or the action someone will take, takes, is taking or took.
dojg.meaning: Only; just; be ready to do something; have just done something; just did something; be just doing something; about

examples.japanese: (ksa).デザートは食べるばかりになっている・います。
examples.english: The only thing left to do with the dessert is to eat it./The dessert is ready to eat.

examples.japanese: (ksb).友子は遊んでばかりいる・います。
examples.english: The only thing Tomoko is doing is playing./Tomoko is doing nothing but playing.

examples.japanese: (ksc).私は昼ご飯を食べたばかりだ・です。
examples.english: I had my lunch and haven't done anything else since then./I have just eaten my lunch.

examples.japanese: (ksd).このレストランは安いばかりだ・です。
examples.english: The only merit of this restaurant is that the food is inexpensive./This restaurant is just cheap.

examples.japanese: (kse).デニスはビールばかり飲んでいる・います
examples.english: Dennis is drinking only beer.

examples.japanese: (ksf).私は一月ばかりパリにいた・いました。
examples.english: I was in Paris for about a month.

examples.japanese: (a).このレポートはあと結論を書くばかりだ。
examples.english: The only thing left to do with this report is to write a conclusion.

examples.japanese: (b).春江は泣いてばかりいて何も話そうとしない。
examples.english: Harue is just crying and won't talk about anything.

examples.japanese: (c).松山さんは今シカゴに着いたばかりです。
examples.english: Mr. Matsuyama has just arrived in Chicago now.

examples.japanese: (d).この仕事は面倒なばかりであまり儲かりません。
examples.english: This job is troublesome and doesn't bring us big profits.

examples.japanese: (e).この寮に住んでいるのは男子学生ばかりだ。
examples.english: The students who are living in this dorm are all boys.

examples.japanese: (f).フィッシャー先生はリサとばかり話している。
examples.english: Professor Fisher is talking only with Lisa.

examples.japanese: (g).十人ばかりの友達が手伝ってくれました。
examples.english: About ten friends helped me.

dojg.writeup: ## 1. The basic idea which ばかり expresses is that there is nothing except what is stated. When Verb infornmal nonpast precedes ばかり, the whole expression means there is nothing left to do (to complete something) but what is stated by the verb. In some contexts, Verb informal nonpast ばかり means that someone does nothing but what is stated. Example:
